Jazz Age chronicler. The American Dream’s shadow side.

F. Scott Fitzgerald’s name is tied to the 1920s—glittering parties, fast cars, and the crash that followed.
He wrote like someone racing against time, because he was.
His first novel, This Side of Paradise (1920), made him famous at 23.
But The Great Gatsby (1925) is why we still read him.
Gatsby isn’t just a rich man throwing parties—it’s a man who built a fortune to win back a woman who’d never love him the same way.
Fitzgerald knew that longing.
He and his wife Zelda burned through money, fame, and each other, their love as dazzling as it was destructive.
His sentences sparkle, but the stories underneath are about failure.
Gatsby’s green light.
Dick Diver’s cracked psyche in Tender Is the Night.
Even his own life: dead at 44, his final novel unfinished, his obituaries calling him a has-been.
Now he’s the voice of an era—proof that the brightest flames cast the longest shadows.

The cost of obsession.
Art built from ruin.
Why we mythologize the past.
